relationships.notes: Martha welcomes Jesus into the Bethany home, dialogues with him about discipleship and resurrection, and serves at the banquet celebrating Lazarus’s raising.
John portrays Martha and Mary sending for Jesus on Lazarus’s behalf, lamenting his death, and witnessing his restoration, underscoring Martha’s familial advocacy.
The two Bethany sisters embody complementary expressions of discipleship—Martha’s active service and confession alongside Mary’s contemplative devotion—within the same household scenes.

traits.hospitality_role: Welcomes Jesus into her home and is busy with much serving while her sister Mary sits at Jesus’s feet listening to his word.
traits.gentle_rebuke: Receives Jesus’s response that she is anxious and troubled about many things, while Mary has chosen the better part that will not be taken away from her.
traits.symbolic_reading: Often interpreted as representing the tension between active service and contemplative listening in discipleship.

traits.sister_of_lazarus: Appears as one of the sisters of Lazarus, who sends word to Jesus about her brother’s illness.
traits.dialogue_about_resurrection: Engages Jesus in a dialogue about resurrection, expressing belief in a future resurrection and then confessing Jesus as the Messiah, the Son of God.
traits.participation_in_sign: Witnesses Jesus’s raising of Lazarus and participates in the family hospitality at the subsequent banquet in Bethany.
